The best and most powerful lies have elements of truth. It’s true that the direct radiation from the Sun cannot reconcile measured values of global average surface temperature. THE GREENHOUSE EFFECT IS ADIABATIC HEATING IN REALITY. Adiabatic heating is the raising of T by adding work energy (N x m) without exchange of heat energy (Joules(J) which is also = N x m).

The Sun does the work of inflating the atmosphere against the force of gravity in the same way you do physical work climbing up to the top of a cliff. On top of a cliff, you have potential energy. If you do a base jump, your potential energy is converted to kinetic energy as you fall (i.e. when you speed up). Atm pressure (caused by gravity together with the mass of the atmosphere) causes thermal (=kinetic) energy in the case of gases.

Any volume V of any gas at pressure P has a steady and constant thermal energy P(N/m2) x V (m3) = N x m = J(Joules) = nRT as a result of this kinetic energy of its molecules. Thus for a given mole amount of gas ( n), PV/T = nR (a constant) or P1V1/T1=P2V2/T2.

T1 =214 K +/- (Temperature from solar radiation @Tropopause)
V1/V2 = 3.3 expansion ratio of any gas from 101 to 23 Pascal (P @tropopause)
T2 = P2V2/P1V1 x T1 (above gas law solved for T2=predicted T@surface)
= 101.3x1/(22.8 x 3.3) x 214
= 288 K (Earth Surface, subject to minor variations +/-1 K associated with albedo and imperfect adiabatic system)

I agree that we need to never look at solid boosters again. Currently, our CO2 levels are over 400PPM, at average Earth temp, about 17C. Putting things into perspective, we have to remember that most life evolved, in the past 600 million years under an average temp of 20C and 5000PPM CO2. Most of this carbon has already been sequestered by the Earth and we'll never get it back. Plants die around 150PPM, so we already were facing a carbon-extinction event until the discovery of fossil fuels extraction, which set that back a few hundred million years (more plant life is good, right?)
Its a long road, and we'll run out of fossil fuels about the same time we replace them, as long as we let innovators like Elon Musk keep doing their thing, without slowing them down. The climate will keep changing, but if we cut off fossil fuels tomorrow, we have to realize half the world's population would starve, as they are dependent upon that energy. That would be a lot more catastrophic than to just let Elon Musk solve it for us, in his own time. Again, we just need to keep the innovation going and it'll be a soft landing. History has shown that the road of tempered innovation, even into rocketry will ultimately benefit all of mankind.

As you said, producing a rocket pollutes from the building process and materials used. That's the same with renewable energy sources. Solar panels or wind turbines use a lot of materials and land, so they're not carbon neutral. Another climate friendly option is nuclear energy, which uses far less materials per energy output and lasts for long. Nuclear energy emits around 6 times fewer CO2 per kWh produced than solar panels (check IPCC for figures). 
And when it comes to costs, to reach a more affordable production of hydrogen you need to run the electrolysers 24/7. That's not compatible with intermittent solar or wind energy. So nuclear energy may be the best source of clean hydrogen in the future.
Other processes, like methane pyrolysis (also referred as blue hydrogen) may be very interesting in the hopefully near future. But that's for Earth production, not sure it would be feasible on Mars!

I have always wondered why the initial plume, at the moment of lift-off is not captured and filtered. At least clean up what can be cleaned up. I also wonder why the Rockets, which are obviously extremely heavy, are not assisted at lift off. If they were sat on a pad that takes the weight of the rocket and uses it to load tension into a spring system. That would effectively mean the first G would be reduced considerably. I have also wondered how solar panels in space compare. Surely they would be more efficient? I am not sure about the cost efficiency but as far as Mars is concerned, at least to get started, can't we just carry empty batteries up into space and drop charged ones back down to Mars as a renewable payload? Less setup time than building power plants and far less difficulty to help establish a base as batteries can be added to separate buildings without wires. A cordless society! The tech and resources can be developed here then shipped to Mars, especially with rollout solar panels which are not to hard to deploy. A ship goes there, auto rolls out the panels and begins charging and dropping batteries to Mars.

It is not because improvements will be made in one sector (say electrification of the car fleet), that other sectors should feel free to pollute more. So, point to point transportation by rockets seem to me to be a non starter. Let’s keep rockets to put useful loads into orbit, and accept spending some hours in an airliner, when one absolutely, positively need to do an inter-continental flight. Such a moderation (I prefer this word to limitation) of air travel to what is truly necessary could be achieved by putting an appropriate carbon tax on jet fuel... and other fuel also, while at it. Otherwise, mankind is soon going to hit a wall... at orbital speed! The new IPCC report is pretty clear on that matter!

Climate scientists will typically preface when talking about CO2 that it is a very mild greenhouse gas with water vapor being a much more powerful greenhouse gas. Water vapor overlaps the inferred blocking wave lengths of CO2 except for a small window and is some 45 times more concentrated in the atmosphere. A note: greenhouse gases as typically discussed block inferred radiation from the earth's surface from escaping out to space. Their interaction with solar radiation is not a big topic of popular discussion. Water vapor and steam are invisible. Condensing water vapor and steam appear white as seen during rocket launches.

CO2 in the atmosphere converts high energy ultraviolet solar radiation into longer wave lengths more conducive to heating the earths surface. This is CO2's primary means of heating the earth and is thought to provide the earth with some 50°C of additional temperature. This takes place with very low levels of CO2 at 10 - 50 ppm to reach saturation with present day concentrations being around 350 ppm and there is no ultraviolet radiation in the wave length CO2 does this conversion hitting the earth's surface. There is a giant spike in the CO2 converted wavelengths hitting the earth's surface. This is NOT a greenhouse gas mechanism.  

As a greenhouse gas CO2 has a natural log relationship with larger concentration having smaller effects in radiation forcing and may go hyper log rhythmic at multiples of todays concentration. CO2's forcing effect is small at some 1.4 W/m^2 inferred energy retention predicted by an attitude of 20 km for an increase of CO2 from 250 ppm preindustrial to 350 ppm of today. As a comparison a solar panel is typically rated at a solar radiation of 1000 W/m^2 and on a typical good day will see 500 W/m^2.

Very nice Video, but of course there are some slips that, in all fairness, you can not avoid completely. If you compare Rockets to Airliners, then you have to look on their practical and societal uses. There are so many airliners, because they serve a purpose to society - a purpose that in wide parts can not be replaced by rockets (midrange travel). So just putting the different numbers up there rather becomes a part of an "whataboutism", You could equally excuse anything with that argument that just happens in a niche, like car racing / racing cars on public streets, military emissions, etc. pp.
The question is not: "Has this a large percentage on overall pollution?" but "is this additional pollution worth the purpose it serves". Almost nothing apart from general transportation, electricity generation and heating has large impacts on pollution, if singeled out - but the sum of the small niches still delivers a huge part of overall pollution. So - you just can't absolve Rockets from producing emissions by saying "there are not that many of them".

If a rocket is used as travel devices for millionaires to have an exiting "holiday in space" than its emissions are completely avoidable - this serves virtually no benefit to society. It just would be a totally unneccessary purpose, a sign of pollution as a right to a decandent elite. This is of course also true for yachts, etc. - but this is again a whataboutism and would do nothing to justify Spaceflight as a thrillride for millionaires. E.g. Bransons complete "space"-company is nothing than an elaborate amusement park ride...

Of course some rocket starts serve important scientific purposes - but manned spaceflight in general would be highly debatable in this discussion - a mars mission with its thousands of neccessary rockets starts during the programm leading to the final mission could also be debated in its use to humanity.

maybe i'm wrong, but it's worth comparing transportations emissions to miles traveled..a 737 for instance (which has 189 seats btw, bringing your calculations to 0.317) should be observed differently in my opinion : the ratio of fuel per pax per 100km (roughly 54 nautical miles).

Now, a 737 cruises at roughly 2.4 tons per hour. we can roughly say that continous descent compensates for the extra burn during climb (for the "ish" side of things). Now in average, we cruise at lets say 0.78 mach, which in still air is roughly 7.5nm a minute (about 13.9 km/min). This says that, in still air, we are taking 7.5 minutes to achieve those 54 nm (100km), right ?

And it goes like this : 2400 /60 = 40 kg/min -> 40kg *7.5 = 300kg...300kg for 189 people..which is 1.6 kg per passenger per 100km..which is roughly 1.8 liter of fuel in cruise.
Should you even double that for approximation (apu, taxi, takeoff, climb, cruise descent, taxi)...my car is doing about 7 liters/100km on a highway, and its probably rated much less then "0.317".

Extracting CO2 from the air is super-super inefficient. CO2 in air is only 400 ppm. Doing the entropy calculations the absolute minimum energy requirement for separating this 400 ppm from air is 74 MJ/kgCO2. This ignores all process inefficiencies. This is about 5 times the thermal energy you get from burning the amount of methane that it takes to produce a kg of CO2. That's a terrible idea don't spread it around.

The only proposals for carbon capture are in situations (like fossil fuel plants) where the CO2 is contained and can be processed before it mixes with the air. If you wanted to do this with a rocket you'd have to capture the emissions before it mixed with air ... it doesn't really work.

Ok so each starship will emit 660 tonnes CO2 and each super heavy will produce 1815 tonnes. Let's simplify and assume they always launch together and round up to 2500 tonnes per launch.

Current world CO2 output is on order 40 Gt/yr = 110 Mt/day. For comparison the world airlines produced about 900 Mt/yt = 2.5 Mt/day.

So each Starship stack launch per day will add 0.1% to world aviation CO2 emissions and 23 ppm to world total emissions.

Tesla has a counter on its website claiming total CO2 emissions saved. Today this is ticking up at 245 tonnes per day with a fleet of half a million.

So for Tesla's savings to cancel out SpaceX's excess, they need about 5 million Teslas on the road for every Starship stack launch per day.

That sounds like a pretty plausible ratio to me.

Obviously this ignores all manufacturing costs.

I am always very skeptical about 'green' solutions that still require putting greenhouse gasses into the atmosphere.

For example, at least where I live, wood burning power plants are considered green energy and carbon neutral because any carbon released have been absorbed by the trees. So, according to that logic, when you combine deforestation and polluting the atmosphere you suddenly get a clean source of energy.

There was also a proposed car fuel source a few years ago, I forgot which, but it required equal amounts of CO2 to create the fuel as would be emitted, so it's carbon neutral and was being marketed as a green fuel source. But, in all likelihood, it'd be cheaper to make new CO2 to create the fuel than it is to get it from the atmosphere, so in reality it would probably just be another polluting fuel.

And finally carbon capture. It's an interesting technology that should certainly be developed further, but I don't actually see it happening. There is basically zero economic incentive to creating them, neither for companies nor governments. So, while a few might be built as a token to show how good your company or political party is at fighting climate change, but not nearly enough to make a real impact. In fact, they may actually be harmful if they start to be used to justify putting a bunch of CO2 into the atmosphere.

One thing that could fix a lot of these is a carbon tax and an equally large carbon capture subsidy. The details are incredibly complex, but an imperfect carbon tax would be loads better than none at all. Besides, this is what lawyers are for. However, somehow even UBI seems to be more politically viable.

Especially if many rocket engines run rich, I think it's important to look at the unburnt fuel that comes out of the end as well, especially in the case of methane. It probably doesn't matter in the grand scheme of things, but I would still say that omitting it is a weak point of your analysis.
Also, manufacturing pollution might be a gigantic rabbit hole, it is an extremely important one, considering even reusable rockets only fly a couple of times. But also the manufacturing of the fuel could add a lot to how polluting that fuel is. So, even very rough ballparks would've added a lot to this analysis.
Though, of course, there being more to unpack doesn't mean the analysis is bad. It was a really interesting and well researched video.

I could write several books about Climate Science and false narratives being pushed, but as you stated you do not want to make this the page of debate for that.
Therefore I would just like to leave you with 1 Comment regarding CO2. And that is that CO2 is NOT a problem.
The Earth has been around for billions of years. Life has been around for a long time too. And for MOST of the time that there has been life on the planet CO2 levels were MUCH higher than they are now not by percentages but by multiples.
In fact we are at a level of CO2 now that is dangerously low for life. We went so low in previous ice ages that all life was almost terminated on earth. This is because so much of the Carbon necessary for life over time has been trapped and during previous ice ages the levels almost dropped below the level necessary for plant life.. Certain forms of life like Shelfish for instance have learned to use CO2 in their shells, and when these organizms die, they trap this CO2 which over time is buried and sinks to lower and lower stratifications in the earths layers. This is actually where a lot of fossil fuel comes from in the first place..
Burning of fossil fuels actually re-introduces this CO2 back into the eco-system and the CO2 starved plants are very thankful indeed, even tho for the most part, even with rockets, we only produce a small fraction of CO2 compared to Nature. The fear of some scientists is that without man, so much CO2 would be trapped in time that a subsequent ice age would do what the last one failed to do, basically wipe out all life due to hyper low CO2 levels.
Ideally our CO2 levels would be 4 to 6 times higher than they are now. Plants life would be much healthier and larger, food much easier to produce. Animals much easier to feed.
And when these more typical conditions existed in the past, there was no negative effect from a climate standpoint because of the way the entire system regulates itself, which is far more complex than current infantile models show. In fact most of the models are designed to prove a theory, rather than to expose a truth, but I digress.
There is also no CO2 emergency now, unless you consider historically low levels of CO2 a hardship. Our earths history makes this truth self evident. Man just looks at the blink he exists in, and calls THIS moment normal, and anything outside of it catastrophic. This is an understandable, but flawed approach. Science should not assume. All times and all conditions are relevant evidence here.
We are recovering from Ice ages. Of course glaciers may recede over time, and CO2 will increase, with us or without us. Temperature will also increase, very slowly. I'm talking thousands of years.
And believe me, this is the right direction and the right speed. We are fortunate to be in the position we are now, where CO2 and temperature are on the uptick. Both of these will actually be a net gain for life on earth. For each area they say might turn into a desert, that probably already is close, we will open 4X as much temperate zones for food production and living comfortably..
And with the self regulation of the weather Hot areas tend to cool themselves, and Cool areas tend to warm themselves. Clouds and water vapor work to negate extremes and balance temperatures quite well.
Also consider that much of our current severe weather systems are based on cooler northern air (or southern if you live in Australia) coming down towards the equator. Far from there being more storms in the future, the evening of world temperatures into less extremes would mean less violent storms across different climactic areas.
This is the earth returning towards what is more normal, warmer temperatures, and sufficient CO2. And we will be fine, the earth has gone thru this cycle countless times before. Rather than making models to predict what high CO2 would look like, perhaps the scientists could look at the past. The life then didn't seem to mind. All signs are of abundance that far exceeds anything we enjoy today. One of the reasons everything was much larger. Fauna and Flora are small and sickly compared to the animals of other eras that were not gas starved.
Rockets should hopefully be as efficient as possible, and limit pollutants, but of all the emissions they make, CO2, despite popular opinion, is the least worry of all. CO2 is the gas of life. A noble gas that we benefit from and that is necessary for the creation of oxygen via photosynthesis. Even concerns of radiative forcing usually do not consider that although less energy is allowed to leave the atmosphere, less energy is also absorbed from the sun in the first place because the effect works BOTH ways, not just ONE way. The earth never burned up before when we had levels in the thousands of parts per million (we are in the hundreds of parts per million now), and it won't burn up this time.
Plants and animals will be more disease free and healthier. We do not realize it because this is the era we exist in but we are starved for oxygen and CO2 and a move towards more of those gasses and further from an Ice age, is the best possible scenario. @everyday astronaut This is a VERY important message. You've been a crucial voice in educating the public about our space programs and you do so with a positive attitude. I don't think you'll get too much flack for mentioning the environment, it's very important. On the conservative end of things, I think what they often don't like is being spoken down to if they disagree with a climate change solution or prediction but liberals also have their own concerns about being poked at an immature fashion. Both the right and left seem to bicker back and forth on this topic. With that said, I'm sure you've gained support from everyday people who have a wide range of beliefs because you've stayed apolitical from what I can see. I probably follow politics as closely as you follow Spacex so I know from experience what happens when people with clashing beliefs don't get along.

You spoke about how you don't agree that NASA and SpaceX should be in competition with each other. That mentality of them VS. us is far worse when it comes to politics which is why I get saddened when those who advocate for our space programs get too aggressive with going after the beliefs of those who have a different set of values or when they get too aggressive with going after major political figures. I worry about that because it divides their supporters along ideological lines and I think it's so important that the public is educated on matters of science. I think Bill Nye has made that mistake along with Astrophysicist Robert Zubrin, both of whom I think are valuable to the scientific community but who have pushed some of their followers away. I know this by speaking to and looking at the comments of some of their followers.
It's my belief that as scientists or science enthusiasts, we should be pragmatic in our approach to learning or teaching. Elon Musk has been fantastic in this regard, he does occasionally make public statements that stir the pot but he's willing to speak to people on both sides of the political aisle. He's obviously not on the political left or on the right. Personally, I'm more conservative so it excites me to see conservative politicians fighting to fund NASA and supporting SpaceX but I can also appreciate when a typically left-leaning news network gives a lot of coverage to developments with SpaceX and NASA. We should be coming together to fight for these programs and thankfully support is coming from multiple directions right now.
The only thing I have to say as a conservative is that there are a LOT of us interested in science, SpaceX and NASA just as with liberals who are interested. You've done amazing at keeping a positive and inclusive spirit. Not only is that important in regards to race and sex, it can be important on political matters as well. NEVER let that die because it's too rare. We all have our opinions and the right to express them but when there are divisive comments or a singling out of the mistakes made by one group over another, it can be off-putting and steer so many people away from what are good causes. This is especially true on matters of science, personally, I believe they should be separated from political biases as much as possible.

Ok, my feedback:
@26:30: forget CO2 It's not an environmental issue. Ozone or Ozone depleating is in fact critical. But keep in mind that ozone is produced out of O2, which is very abondoned in the atmosphere (20 %). Ozone not only plays an inportant role in filtering high energy radiation, it is also important to sustain the 3 lower layers of the atmosphere, where the troposphere is the lowest. The troposphere is very critical for containing the convection below 7-15 km and therefore conserve the heat where it's needed. It therefore can be said, that ozone is not only a filter of dangerous radiation, it's also the one and only greenhouse gas there is. Water vapor plays a regulating role, due to the fact that it's the only atmospheric gas that is able to condensate and form clouds. Water vapotr and aerosoles in the stratosphere are critical, aswell as Ozone depleating gasses. CO2 is not a factor in the complete atmosphere, it even doesn't block the radiation in the 15 micrometer band (radiation window). The same is true for water vapor, although it strongly absorbs in this band.

The real question here is: how many aerosoles and water vapor are injected into the stratosphere, because that's the layer where the ozone layer is located at and that's the place on which tropospheric convection depends on.
Aerosoles in the troposphere get cleaned out by condensed water and will be carried back to the ground, so they are not harmful.

I did not get busy with the mesosphere and the thermosphere, but these seem not to play a big role in the earths climate.

The radiation equilibrium is neither influenced by CO2 nor by H2O. These gasses simply scatter and therefore delay radiation cooling. The way more imporant part is taken by Ozone and it's resulting tropospheric convection.

This is not political. These are the physical facts.

Before rockets get to the volume to where they become a significant pollution problem, one thought I have circled around for years is the Orbital Launch Ring, and a fairly specific one at that. More specifically:
1. Have a stationary tube with a super-orbital speed rotor inside.
2. Wraps around the planet. Preferably around the equator, but could be at any inclination.
3. Heavy use of magnets and superconductors to both operate (such as levitating the rotor in the ring), to maximize performance of electromagnets, and ship massive amounts of power around the ring.
4. Suspend high voltage direct current (HVDC) high temperature superconducting (HTSC) power line in the shadow of the ring to distribute power around the ring.
5. Put a maglev track on top, probably similar to a Japanese maglev train where the electromagnets are on the sides, providing more room for movement.
6. Placed at an altitude of 80km with the super-orbital speed rotor keeping it up through centripetal force. A particular notion on this is to have the rotor going at say 15 km/s so in case the ring catastrophically fails, the rotor will fly off into deep space while the rest of the ring could parachute back to Earth.
7. Tethered to the Earth inverted suspension bridge style and have the tether lines group up say 20 km in altitude before the bundle makes it the rest of the way to the surface. Also have these anchor points to the Earth say 20 km apart so there is room for redundant cross hatching of tether lines to the ring.
8. The ring and rotor are made from mass produced segments. At this the tube could have rolling O-rings at the junction points, an outer seal, and if build on Earth, anti-barnacle paint for being suspended in the ocean below the surface before raising to the operating altitude.
9. Various passive and active stabilization mechanisms such as guy wires at harmonic nodes, tensioners, etc, to dampen out vibrations.
10. For high capacity to and from the ring, use inflatable towers with vertical tracks on them.
11. For both always there power and high capacity power, use a combination of solar panels hanging off of the sides of the ring, conventional power lines running vertical up to the ring from the ground, the HVDC HTSC power line mentioned in #4, and orbiting power satellites beaming power to the ring, launched from the ring.
12. For the vehicles transiting the ring, use a two part cart that is always in the track and the space vehicle mounted on it. Use maglev train style acceleration with superconductors to get up 0G (orbital speed), flip over, and continue to accelerate until reaching the desired speed to be flung off into space. Use a small kick motor to make the final orbital adjustments and to fly back to the ring if desired. The notion being without exceeding an additional 1G on your body, anywhere in the Earth - Moon system can be reached and can go to Earth - Sun Lagrange points.
13. For the return trip to the ring, use regenerative breaking to slow down, potentially using that power for more launches. This can be especially handy if you have say 'ringmax' (space version of panamax) nuclear propulsed ships releasing their 'containers' (space vehicles) while approaching the moon in a free lunar return trajectory, then swings around to the Earth - Moon L2 Lagrange point to pick up more 'containers' to carry out to deep space, say to the asteroid belt for large scale mining operations or Mars for a fast "cruise ship" run or even to some place in the outer solar system such as Titan for hydrocarbons or swoop through the outer atmosphere of a gas giant collecting up that o so rare on Earth helium. This way a nuclear propelled ship never uses its nuclear drive closer to Earth than the Earth - Moon L2 Lagrange point, which should be a safe enough distance to not harm Earth's biosphere and the ring acts as a conveyor belt of sorts to mass move materials from such a nuclear propulsed ship. Even the original project Orion ships would be a vast improvement over chemical rockets in deep space and this would mean a ship like this could finally be used safely as the ring pushes the closest point such a ship needs to get to Earth pretty far away.
13. The materials for a ring like this already exist on Earth in the quantities needed as one of the beauties of a ring structure is they already exist around other planets without needing any special materials and an artificial Earth based one would only need materials already in industrial scale commercial use (though some of the materials would need to have their production rates ramped up for the construction of the ring). However if space mining operations are already happening due to say the BFR rocket, could potentially source some of the materials from space or possibly get space manufacturing up high enough to build the whole ring in space. So there are potential options to either build this in space and attach to the ground or build on the ground and have it move itself to the operating altitude.

The notion for building such a ring structure goes along the lines of the SpaceX Starship / Superheavy and Blue Origin New Glen rockets are really opening up space and we want / need to go to the next level. Especially if we want to do things like send enough solar shading satellites to the Earth-Sun L1 Lagrange point to halt global warming in its tracks while we work on longer term solutions, do large scale space based mining, large scale solar power satellites, and especially want to get to Jeff Bezos' vision of moving industry into space and turning Earth into one big residential zone / becoming a true space fairing civilization in general, you just can't do that with rockets as you are finding out. The only structure I have come up with that can potentially ramp up to this scale is the launch ring built more or less to how I specify here, which should scale up to terawatt scale electrical power, numerous vehicles getting on and off the ring every second weighing in the 100+ tonne scale per vehicle, chemical propulsion in near Earth space used to the smallest degree possible with the ring doing the heavy lifting (and it seems you have pinned down the best fuels for this), maglev tracks on the Moon, say on Olympus Mons on Mars (pokes above the atmosphere, which is handy for high speed surface launch and landing travel), and other low gravity, no atmosphere moons and dwarf planets. The Orbital Launch Ring, a literal maglev railway to and from space, is the real missing piece to having a future more like in the Expanse, not a radically new nuclear powered engine, though I suppose a better fusion drive engine would be a big step up from say the Project Orion nuclear pulse designs. (Plus using water for oxygen would make more sense if you just fused the hydrogen byproduct for both energy and propulsion.)

If you look at a jet engine's thrust is it's mostly the turbofan, a ducted fan pulling air in and throwing it out the back very fast. This is driven by a turbine, so the jet engine is essentially a sijple efficient turbine engine driving a fan. Very little thrust is from the exhaust. For a rocket it's 100% the cumbustion exhaust, and it needs a huge amount of burning fuel to produce thrust. So it's going to be insanely inefficient, but a jet can't operate in space, nor can it gain the speeds needed for orbit. So it is what it is.

In the last 70's we conducted studies in augmenting the level of CO2 in greenhouses and discovered that increasing CO2 above 1,200ppm (four times today's levels) you received increase growth, reduction in water, fertilizer, pesticide, fungicide requirements. Many of today's industrial hydroponic greenhouse and cannabis production facilities use very high CO2 levels. cannabis has been grown at levels as high as 10,000 ppm with remarkable results in growth, flowering and overall production (toxic level for humans).



NASA discovered that in the Midwest Corn and Soybeans fields are massive CO2 sinks. By late afternoon, CO2 can plummet to 200PPM or less, during the night the CO2 levels begin to rise again back to the current 390 PPM or so. In fact Rain forests contribute little to reductions of CO2, but are major producers of Methane due to the rapidly decaying vegetable matter. If you are bent on reducing atmospheric CO2, the best things would be to cut down the Rain forest and plant soybeans, agricultural crops absorb massive amounts of CO2 and emit little methane (which is by far a gas of greater concern). The problem we have on this planet is that we are actually in a CO2 drought. Vast quantities of CO2 have been locked up in fossil fuels and limestone. To feed a hungry planet, especially the push to move away from eating meats which are the product of low quality food stocks, to a plant-based diet, will entail massive amounts of fertilizer, water and pesticides or increase CO2 levels to 1,200 ppm or high world wide. CO2 is an interesting molecule in that its a reverse exponential molecule. The higher the concentration, the less the effect observed. So if you have 600 ppm the "green house" effect will not be twice the effect of 300 ppm but substantially less.

Climate change is real but there is nothing we can do about it or should try to do about it. We must adapt as we have always over the last 50,000 years.

here is why solving an issue like climate change is incredibly difficult.


Let's say I make toilet paper. I use standard industry practice, which has almost a century of experience making paper product production cheaper and more volume oriented. One day some researcher in a lab in Florida gets paid 20k by the EPA to prove that my use of lignin solvents is hazardous to ozone. (In reality, century lows in solar activity and decreased sunspots lowered the near band UV radiation, the leading factor in UV production, which is self regulating, because the more UV, the more ozone is produced to block that UV). Now understand that ozone is highly volatile, almost anything can cause it to break down in a lab. So I get a call from a federal review board saying that they will tax 15% on all my production volume that uses that particular solvent. Ok, not so bad, you could argue that my lignin solvent is pretty nasty stuff, and should be phased out. Well now I'm faced with an increase in retail price of about $1.20 per 12 rolls. A herd of hippie college grads with art majors and no knowledge of reality swarm my product online, and shame customers from my company even though literally every brand uses the same process. So I pay some geek out of environmental engineering school to figure out a more environmentally friendly alternative for my solvent. Turns out the tissue industry already has one, so I spend 500 million dollars across my 12 billion a year manufacturing chain to change solvents. Well now my tp costs $7 per unit instead of $5 per unit, but in a more environmentally conscious age, maybe the public will accept this. Nope, some Chinese competitor I've never heard of starts using my previous solvent, charges $6 per roll, and dumps all their used solvents into a lake. They steal all my business, and the planet is way worse off.


This is a fictitious scenario, but it happens all the time in nearly every industry field that is taxed by the EPA for carbon emissions, hazardous wastes etc. The fact is that until nations like China are internationally boycotted for their terrible practices, child slave labor, and horrendous emissions, all this will continue. Because a bunch of hippie college grads with no reality experience, who live in an incredibly safe, privileged, and environmentally conscious nation, will always use real problems to justify their uneducated opinions, turning off real decision makers from addressing the real problems, because there will always be an echo chamber media to support them. I know I sound harsh, but if the problems of climate change are as bad as some would have us believe, (and some are, no dispute) children (both young and old) need to shut up, and learn real facts before cramming false ones down everyone's throat.

Two things (which means this is a looong comment):


Re. relying on solar on Mars to refuel, my guess is that subsequent missions to the planet would take advantage of the infrastructure from previous missions, if the goal is to create a permanent base there. This means all those photovoltaic panels from the first mission can be reused for the second, third, and so-on. Even so, it doesn't make sense to ship several tonnes of PV panels there, and then mothball them between missions. It may be more sensible to take advantage of other resources we know are already there. Martian regolith is high in iron and presumably also aluminium, much as is the case on Earth (our planet's crust is 5% iron and 8% aluminium) and either of these can be used to produce mirrors capable of reflecting light onto PV panels, increasing the amount of energy they produce. Even considering the loss of solar energy due to much of it being reflected rather than direct, the fact that the mirrors will be little more than rigid sheets of metal makes them potentially much simpler to produce - a definite advantage under the circumstances. It would require the first landing site to be chosen based on the metal content of the local regolith, and for either the first or second rockets to bring both a metal refinery and CO2 splitting facility (both aluminium and iron refining require carbon). Aluminium production would have the added advantage of also producing oxygen as a waste product. The crew of subsequent rockets could then assemble the mirrors when they arrive, increasing the available energy for things like food production. The ability to produce a stock of metals on-site will also be an advantage if the goal is to create a permanent settlement.


Re long-haul routes: one of the reasons airliners have historically not done many direct flights over really long distances, but instead usually stop at intermediate airports like Dubai or Hong Kong, is that beyond a certain distance (somewhere around 5000 km IIRC) the amount of fuel needed starts climbing really rapidly. This is because the largest chunk of fuel used by an airliner is the same as for a rocket: takeoff and landing. The longer the flight, the more fuel - for both engines and passengers - you need to keep going once you're up in the air. More fuel means a heavier takeoff weight, which increases fuel needed for takeoff, which further increases the weight of the plane. This feedback loop creates an exponential increase in the amount of fuel required for distances beyond about 6-7,000km, so airlines have long reduced their long-haul fuel bill significantly by refueling at intermediate airports. With all but the wealthiest passengers more sensitive to price than creature comforts, it is well worth the increase in transit time.


However there is an ongoing shift towards non-stop flights over really long distances, where the higher prices may be worth it for the convenience. This means P2P may be able to compete if the balance of price and convenience works. Even if rockets do use more fuel, that will be at least partly offset by massively reduced staff costs. the combination of shorter flight times and not serving food means the ratio of cabin-crew man-hours to passengers on Starship will be much, much lower than on a very long-haul airline route.

About the "planting trees" thing - yes, this helps a bit - but not as much as many people are claiming.   The tree absorbs CO2 as it grows - but once it's fully grown it''s only carbon neutral - and when it dies, all of that CO2 goes back into the air as the tree decomposes.  If you use the wood from the tree to build something, then you're delaying the release of the CO2 until the thing you built reaches the end of it's life and decomposes.   The ONLY way for trees to be a net help is if you bury the dead tree in an anoxic environment so it doesn't decompose (and eventually becomes coal - which we must promise not to dig up and burn.   You can do better by planting a self-sustaining forest - then as one tree dies, another grows to take it's place.  But even so, the CO2 absorption is only as the forest gets started - after the first generation of trees are mature - there is no net win.  An average adult tree with a 50cm diameter trunk weighs between 1 and 3 tonnes...most of which is carbohydrates - which are mostly carbon, oxygen and hydrogen (from the water it absorbs).   So planting a tree in a SELF-SUSTAINING FOREST locks away (let's say) 1 tonne of CO2.  1 gallon of gasoline is produces about 10kg of CO2 (including the CO2 generated in refining the gasoline from crude oil).  So planting a tree is about like using 100 gallons less gasoline - or driving 3,000 miles in an average car.  BUT ONLY IF THE FOREST IT'S A PART OF IS THERE *FOREVER*.

However, some points of note:

Starship point-to-point launches are an environmentally bad alternative to airplanes. That should be crystal clear. The industry comparison at 44:22 is deceptive, and should include a gross estimate of how much more CO2 would be emitted if Starships replaced all long haul flights.

The promise of using solar panels to produce methane on Earth is not to be thrown around lightly; if you include Earth's gravity well, satellite launches, Earth point-to-point flights, and all the cargo needed to be sent to Mars, you are looking at orders of magnitude more solar panel area than what Zubrin's paper talks about. SpaceX might use some panels to develop the process, but I'd expect Starships to be powered by fossil methane for the foreseeable future. Musk loves mentioning solar, but Tesla's superchargers were supposed to all be fueled by solar panels and batteries by now.

At 52:40 , the incalculable undertaking of moving our industry and energy production off-world would NOT produce "mild emissions". If you include promises of the future that rockets might give us, then that is what the industry-level comparison should be on. How about comparing airplane emissions to making a million-strong Mars colony?

@25m discussing embodied resources ('manufacturing'). One way to put an approximate value on the totality of the embodied resources is to rely upon economics to provide a useful proxy: dollars. If a single Space Shuttle launch ended up costing about $1B, then a good stand-in proxy for the totality of the embodied resources for each launch is about $1B. If a SpaceX launch only costs about $80M, then that obviously has a vastly less amount of embodied resources. I'm amused by those that are mystified by how to sum up all the embodied resources. While you're trying to come up with a better measure (good luck), the sticker price is a pretty good proxy.

@Everyday Astronaut Nice video!, here some questions and some things to add:
1-Why you use the case of a single starship without the booster for long range passenger transport? Elon used the booster for that, not sure that an starship loaded with 400 passengers (around 50 tons of payload) could reach very far being reusable. I don't know, I am asking.
2-Water vapor is not even comparable with co2, it is a more potent greenhouse gas, but it last only from days to few months (depending the altitude) vs hundreds of years of co2, then we also consider that most of the emissions happen at lower altitude instead at higher altitude.
3- Electrolysis does not consume much energy, today electrolysers are at 90% efficiency, current liquefaction plants are at 70% efficiency, but just scaling up (which you need to make rocket fuel) you can have a plant with 85% of efficiency. One more case, you need to store solar and wind energy one way on another into hydrogen to solve the seasonal disparities and to clean the other 50% of global co2 emissions that came from the utility transport sector and the natural gas grid, those thing can not be solved with batteries (is not practical neither cost efficient).
4-You mention how many football fields of solar panels are needed to make enough fuel for the starship on mars, but you did not mention how much time it would require to fill those, is not the same that amount of panels to refill a starship every 1 month than every 2 years.

I was hoping you could get at least order of magnitude information on the environmental cost of manufacture and disposal of the full set of vehicles.

Looking at economics for cars and houses (and other such things) we try to look at 'life-cycle costs'. Acquisition covers the building, and 'resale value' includes the depreciation that happens for use. -- If someone sells something, they have theoretically embodied the cost of manufacture and initial transportation. If you sell a used car, that person is paying less normally than the acquisition cost, and also must bear the cost of proper disposal (again in theory). So with perfect economics, the ecological impact is already cycled in, but in retrospect we see this hasn't happened. But we still need to get it calculated in somewhere because as a society it is part of the total social cost of products.
